Between 10:30 and 11:15 UTC on Saturday, March 22nd, our internal monitoring system responsible for metrics experienced performance issues due to a sudden load spike. We quickly identified the root cause and applied a fix to stabilize the system.

After thorough analysis, we have confirmed **there was no customer impact during this time**. Additionally, we have implemented performance improvements to further strengthen the resilience of this service.

The upstream incident is ongoing. The following workarounds exist for affected and failing checks:

1. disable the check.
2. remove the `.toHaveScreenshot()` assertion from checks and rerun the check once with `Run script and update golden files` then save. Be careful, it might be the only useful assertion of your check.

We keep monitoring the situation closely and keep sending updates here.

incidents.name: Increased scheduling delay across multiple regions

incident_updates.body:
### Timeline:

* 11:32 UTC: Database migration caused locks on critical tables, leading to temporary API unavailability.

* 11:39 UTC: Database locks were removed, and check scheduling began to recover.

### Impact:

* Our public API was partially unavailable.

* Checks were not scheduled when the locks were effective.

* Delayed checks were eventually processed across all regions.

* Some high-frequency checks \(intervals ≤ 5 minutes\) may have skipped a check run during the incident window.

### Root Cause:

The issue stemmed from a database migration that inadvertently locked critical tables, impacting API and scheduling functionality.

### Resolution:

Once the database locks were removed, system recovery began immediately, with checks processing resuming across all regions.

### Next Steps:

We are reviewing our database migration procedures to minimize locking risks and implementing additional safeguards to ensure API and check scheduling resilience during similar operations.

Feel free to reach out to support if you have any questions. We apologize for the inconvenience and appreciate your understanding as we work to improve our systems.

incidents.name: Increased failure rate for checks in specific regions

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

An incident with our hosting provider Heroku \([https://status.heroku.com/incidents/2677](https://status.heroku.com/incidents/2677)\) caused a partial outage. In particular, this caused our web application and public dashboards to load slowly. It also caused errors for our public API, Terraform, the Checkly CLI, and Heartbeat checks. Since Private Locations rely on the API for fetching check run jobs, check runs on Private Locations were not scheduled correctly during this incident. Check runs on public locations continued running normally during this time, though, and were not affected.

The incident was active on July 29 during 12:15-12:30 UTC, 13:00-13:15 UTC, and 13:45-14:45 UTC.

We have identified a regression causing some Checkly CLI test sessions to fail, affecting `npx checkly test` and `npx checkly trigger`. We are currently putting a fix in place.

**Duration:** 9:37 - 9:40 UTC

‌

**Incident Summary:**

On 10th June 2024, a deployment caused the Check Scheduler service to scale down to 0 instances for a brief period of 3 minutes.

‌

**Root Cause:**

An incorrect feature flag configuration led to the unintended scaling down of the Check Scheduler service during a deployment.

‌

**Impact:**

* **High Frequency Checks \(<5 minutes\):** Skipped executions during the incident.
* **Other Checks:** Experienced a brief scheduling delay of about 3 minutes.

‌

**Resolution:**

The feature flag setting was corrected, and the Check Scheduler service was scaled back to normal.

‌

We apologize for any problems this may have caused. If you have any questions or concerns feel free to contact us via [support@checklyhq.com](mailto:support@checklyhq.com)

incidents.name: Faulty deployment affecting all browser and multistep checks using playwright

incident_updates.body:
A faulty deployment added the **globalTimeout** Playwright configuration option. This option used an un-parsed environment variable set in our architecture, causing the timeout to be a _string_ instead of a _number_.      
For a subset of checks, Playwright failed with the following error: `globalTimeout must be a non-negative number`.

Due to a misconfiguration, the issue went undetected before reaching production. To mitigate and prevent this from happening again, we are leveraging our canary and test environments.

We are sorry for any inconveniences this may have caused.

Some check runs triggered from the Checkly CLI are incorrectly reported as failing in the CLI. This affects both `npx checkly test` and `npx checkly trigger`. When run with `--record`, the check run results are reported correctly in the web UI but may be incorrectly reported as failing in the CLI.

We've identified that the issue is due to errors sending check results to the CLI via WebSocket. We're currently working on a fix.
This incident has been resolved.
We detected an unusual high workload on us-west-1, we provisioned additional capacity to handle that load. We keep monitoring until scheduling delay is back to normal.
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.
